revision.comment: Rescued 2 archive links; reformat 2 links. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} '''2007 Broadway Stagehands Strike''' was a strike action by [[stagehand]]s represented by Theatrical Protective Union Number One (Local One) of the [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] (IATSE) against the Shubert, Jujamcyn, and Nederlander theaters (represented by [[League of American Theatres and Producers]]). The strike (the first in the union's 121-year history)<ref name="Fairness">Steven Greenhouse and Campbell Robertson, "In Broadway Dispute, Questions of Fairness," ''New York Times,'' November 25, 2007.</ref> commenced on November 10, 2007, at 10:00 A.M. in New York City. It was the second strike on Broadway in five years (the other was the [[2003 Broadway Musicians Strike]]).<ref name="Day5">{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=Day 5: Most of Broadway Remains Dark |publisher=Playbill |date=November 14, 2007 |accessdate=November 22, 2007 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112770.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116091348/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112770.html |archivedate=November 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
On November 28, 2007, at 10:30 pm, the two sides announced a settlement to end the strike, with shows beginning the evening of November 29. This was the longest strike to hit Broadway since a 25-day musicians' strike in 1975.<ref name="nyt-end">{{cite news | last=Robertson | first=Campbell | title=Stagehands End Walkout on Broadway |work=New York Times | date=November 29, 2007 | accessdate=November 29, 2007 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/29/theater/29broadway.html}}</ref>
==Background== IATSE Local One engages in [[collective bargaining]] with the League of American Theatres and Producers (the League), an association of Broadway theater owners and producers.
IATSE Local One was formed in 1886, and represents about 3,000 stagehands and other theater workers in the New York City area. Roughly 350 to 500 of its members work for Broadway theaters, building, installing and operating scenery and sound and lighting equipment.<ref name="Lowdown">Campbell Robertson, "Broadway's Showdown: The Lowdown," ''New York Times,'' November 14, 2007.</ref>
The League includes nearly every one of the 39 theaters on Broadway. The [[Jujamcyn Amusement Corporation]] owns five theaters, [[The Shubert Organization]] 17 theaters, and the [[Nederlander Organization]] nine theaters. The remaining members of the League ([[Disney Theatrical]], [[Live Nation]] and six nonprofits) each own a single theater. Generally, Jujamcyn and the Shubert Organization are the only owners represented by the League in negotiations. The Nederlander Organization has a separate contract, but a clause in the contract guarantees that its terms and conditions reflect the contract reached with the League.<ref>This is known as a "me too" contract.</ref> The remaining League members engage in individual contract negotiations with IATSE Local One.<ref name="Bracing">Campbell Robertson, "Stagehands Bracing for Broadway Showdown," ''New York Times,'' July 26, 2007.</ref>
==Events== The [[collective bargaining]] agreement between Local One and the League expired in the summer of 2007. Members of Local One agreed to work without a contract and promised other unions in the entertainment industry that they would not strike until an agreement was reached. In late summer, Local One and the League, representing the Shubert and Jujamcyn theaters with the Nederlander Organization observing, entered into negotiations.<ref name="Bracing" />
===Contract issues=== Contract negotiations generally focused on work rules. Broadway shows offer a standard eight performances per week ("performance calls"), each of which lasts three to four hours. Additionally, there are "load-ins" (periods during which a show moves into a theater), rehearsals, "maintenance calls" (during which scenery, lighting and sound equipment are serviced, repaired and maintained), and opportunities for overtime. The League has accused the union of using its contract to secure [[featherbedding]], a practice made illegal by the federal [[Taft-Hartley Act]]. Among the work rule changes sought by the League were: * '''Loosening load-in rules:''' The load-in period may last several weeks and cost $1 million or more. Current work rules require producers to determine ahead of time how many stagehands are needed on each given day. These numbers cannot change once load-in begins, requiring producers to pay salaries even if no work occurs. The rule ensures that workers will not be on call (and unpaid for it) during the load-in period. The producers proposed essentially eliminating the rule. The union agreed to loosen the rule, but sought to keep a minimum number of stagehands at work each day. * '''Overtime:''' The existing contract stated that if any stagehand is required to work overtime during a load-in, all workers must stay and be paid overtime. The producers proposed loosening the rule so that producers determined how many stagehands would stay and earn overtime. The union agreed to discuss modifying the contract, but only if the League agreed to strengthen other parts of the contract. * '''Performance and continuity calls:''' The existing contract stated that stagehands could only perform work related to the performance during a performance call. If the producer wishes the stagehand to perform other duties, the producer must issue a one-hour "continuity call," even if the stagehand has no more work to do. If the one-hour continuity call is not long enough, producers are required to pay for a four-hour shift. Producers call the rule wasteful, but the union claimed the rule discouraged theaters from forcing employees to work past midnight. The union also noted that many stagehands supplement their income with daytime jobs, and late nights significantly interfere with these arrangements.<ref name="Fairness" /> Producers proposed widening the tasks stagehands may perform during performance calls and reducing the required four hours of pay. The union had agreed to discuss reducing the required four hours of pay in exchange for improving other benefits. * '''Wages''': There are four classes of stagehands. Head carpenters and electricians, who are in the top category, made about $1,600 a week. Most stagehands (riggers, winch-workers and operators) were in the lowest class, making about $1,200 a week. The union claimed that the proposed rule changes would cut workers salaries by 38 percent. The League offered different pay raises for different classes of workers, but the union argued these did not make up for the lost income.<ref name="Lowdown" />
Many labor relations experts said{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} that the negotiations were not about work rules or economics, but the relative power of the two sides. Producers, who pay the theater owners, are also part of the League, and for the first time they took a vocal and active role in pushing for contract changes in order to break the union's control over theater management. Subsequently the League established a $20 million "defense fund" to help theaters weather a strike.<ref name="Fairness" /> In response, the union established a $4 million fund to help its members during a possible job action.<ref name="Bracing" />
===Negotiations and strike=== Contract negotiations stalled between the two parties and the league threatened Local One with a [[Lockout (industry)|lockout]] if it would not comply with their demands. On October 21, Local One held a special meeting and its membership voted to authorize the executive board of the union to take any action deemed necessary, including but not limited to a strike, in order to reach an agreement between the two parties.<ref>Campbell Robertson, "Broadway, Next Week: Shows or Lockouts?", ''New York Times,'' September 26, 2007; "Theater Labor Talks Continue," ''New York Times,'' September 30, 2007; Campbell Robertson, "Manhattan: Broadway Talks Extended," ''New York Times,'' October 5, 2007; Campbell Robertson, "Broadway Shutdown Looms As Talks Reach an Impasse," ''New York Times,'' October 10, 2007; "Broadway's Labor Impasse Continues," ''New York Times,'' October 11, 2007.</ref>
In late October 2007, talks between Local One and the League again ended in a stalemate. On October 16, the League imposed a portion of its final offer (primarily, the proposals regarding new work rules) on the union. For two weeks Local One worked under these rules before talks with the League resumed.<ref>Campbell Robertson, "Broadway Strike Possible as Producers Impose Their Rules," ''New York Times,'' October 17, 2007.</ref> The following day, the Nederlander Organization announced it would not join the Jujamcyn or Schubert owners in imposing the final offer on the union.<ref>Campbell Robertson, "Development In Theater Standoff," ''New York Times,'' October 19, 2007.</ref>
On November 8, talks with the League resumed, this time including [[Thomas C. Short]], international president of IATSE, for part of the negotiation session. After seeing progress being made, President Short left the talks early to assist members affected by the [[2007 Writers Guild of America strike]]. After his departure, the negotiations once more ground to a halt. On the evening of November 9, Local One President James Claffey, Jr. was directed by International President Short to begin a strike on Saturday, November 10, 2007 at 10:00 AM [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|Eastern time]].<ref>Campbell Robertson, "With Talks Stalled, Stagehands' Union Authorizes a Strike," ''New York Times,'' October 22, 2007; Campbell Robertson, "As Stagehands Strike, Shows Don't Go On," ''New York Times,'' November 11, 2007.</ref>
Negotiations resumed between both sides on November 17, 2007 but broke off the following day. All performances of the affected Broadway shows were canceled through November 25. Negotiations between the League and Local One resumed on November 25.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |last2=Hetrick |first2=Adam |title=Day 17: Talks Adjourn, But Negotiations Will Resume Evening of Nov. 26 |publisher=Playbill |date=November 26, 2007 |accessdate=November 26, 2007 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112950.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071128014119/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112950.html |archivedate=November 28, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Negotiations continued November 26 and November 27. The first bargaining session began November 25, and lasted 20 hours. It recessed at dawn on November 26, and resumed later that evening. A 13-hour bargaining session lasted through the night into the early morning hours of November 27. The two sides agreed on work rules regarding "load-in"—the period when productions are moved into theaters. Talks concerning work rules governing rehearsals and other kinds of work progressed only slowly and incrementally. Economic issues, such as wages, had yet to be seriously discussed. Although producers canceled all shows through Wednesday, November 28, observers noted that the talks had only taken a break and had not appeared to actually break off.<ref name="Campbell">Campbell Robertson, "Broadway Talks Break Up Without a Deal," ''New York Times,'' November 27, 2007.</ref>
===Strike's end=== Both sides applauded the agreement. The union and League agreed to flexibility in the ability to dismiss stagehands during load-in, so long as there was a daily minimum of 17 stagehands on duty at all times. The parties also agreed to extend the continuity call to two hours before or after a performance. However, employees who work the post-performance continuity call earn double pay for the first hour of the two-hour continuity call. Union members also won raises significantly higher than the 3.5 percent increase the League had publicly offered.<ref name="nyt-end" />
The strike was a costly one. At least one estimate placed losses by theater owners and producers at $34.8 million through Sunday, November 25. The New York City comptroller's office said the city had lost another $40 million in revenue through November 28.<ref name="nyt-end" />
==Unions Honoring the Strike== {{Portal|Organized labour}} Below is a list of unions and IATSE Locals honoring Local One's strike:
* All Pink Contract IATSE Stagehands employed in affected buildings * IATSE Theatrical Wardrobe Union, Local 764 * IATSE Treasurers and Ticket Takers, Local 751 * [[Actors' Equity Association|Actors Equity Association, The union of professional Actors and Stage Managers (AEA)]] * [[American Federation of Musicians]], Local 802 * IATSE Theater Ushers Union, Local 306 * United Scenic Artists, IATSE Local 829 * IATSE Hairstylist and Make-Up Artist Local 798
==Effects of the strike== The first show to be affected by the strike was ''[[Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical]]'' at the St. James theater. Stagehands reported to work at their normal time, and after one hour of working left the building and formed picket lines outside. However, because the controlling contract fell outside the union dispute, pickets in front of the theater ended.<ref name="Campbell" />
The strike halted business for all other affected shows. However, unaffected Broadway shows, various [[Off-Broadway]] and [[Off-Off-Broadway]] productions, and other live entertainment such as the ''[[Radio City Christmas Spectacular]]'' and ''[[WINTUK (Cirque du Soleil)|Wintuk]]'', all experienced a boom in sales and attendance.<ref name="Day5" />
The impact of the strike was severe. The [[New York City Comptroller]] estimated that the city had lost $2 million a day in tax revenue because of the strike. Many businesses in and around [[Times Square]] also suffered significant financial losses.<ref>Campbell Robertson, "On Broadway, Gloom Hangs Over Holidays," ''New York Times,'' November 20, 2007.</ref> The charity group [[Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS]] saw a dramatic drop in donations due to the strike, because it normally relies on donations from theater patrons after performances.<ref>Viola, Tom.[http://www.broadwaycares.org/news/strike.pdf "Strike News Release"] BroadwayCares.org, November 12, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414114002/http://www.broadwaycares.org/news/strike.pdf |date=April 14, 2008 }}</ref> BC/EFA launched an internet donation campaign called "Team Raiser" to offset losses.
Below is a list of shows affected and unaffected by the strike. All Off- and Off-Off-Broadway shows were unaffected.
===Running shows affected by the strike=== * ''[[Avenue Q]]'' * ''[[A Bronx Tale (play)|A Bronx Tale]]'' * ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'' * ''[[A Chorus Line]]'' * ''[[The Color Purple (musical)|The Color Purple]]'' * ''[[Curtains (musical)|Curtains]]'' * ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'' * ''[[The Drowsy Chaperone]]'' * ''Duran Duran'' — This show finished its run. The final three shows were combined to two dates and relocated to the Roseland Ballroom.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=Duran Duran Will Play Final "Broadway" Shows at Roseland Ballroom |publisher=Playbill |date=November 11, 2007 |accessdate=November 22, 2007 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112693.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113161413/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112693.html |archivedate=November 13, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'' * ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]'' * ''[[Jersey Boys]]'' * ''[[Legally Blonde (musical)|Legally Blonde]]'' * ''[[Les Miserables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' * ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'' * ''[[Mamma Mia!]]'' * ''[[Monty Python's Spamalot]]'' * ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' * ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'' * ''[[Rock 'n' Roll (play)|Rock 'n' Roll]]'' * ''[[Spring Awakening (musical)|Spring Awakening]]'' — the cast at the time performed the songs from ''Spring Awakening'' on the street outside the [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre]]. * ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]''
===Affected shows that resolved their dispute=== ''[[Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas! (musical)|Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas!]]'' was originally part of the strike, and shut down on November 10 like the other affected shows. The producers of this show were not members of the League, and because of the show's special schedule they had negotiated a separate contract with Local One that was not in dispute. On November 19, the union authorized its members return to work on the show.<ref name="Reopen">{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=UPDATE: Grinch Will Reopen at the St. James Theatre Nov. 23 |publisher=Playbill |date=November 21, 2007 |accessdate=November 22, 2007 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112995.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071123074232/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112995.html |archivedate=November 23, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> However, the owners of the St. James Theater, Jujamcyn Theatres, locked out both producers and stagehands, keeping the show closed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Papa |first=Juliet |title='Grinch' Won't Reopen Until Dispute on Broadway Ends |publisher=1010 Wins |date=November 19, 2007 |accessdate=November 22, 2007 |url=http://www.1010wins.com/pages/1229454.php? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122200141/http://www.1010wins.com/pages/1229454.php |archivedate=November 22, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The producers then sought an injunction in the Manhattan Supreme Court to force the owners to reopen the theater, and on November 21 the judge granted the injunction, allowing the show to re-open on Friday, November 23 at 11:00 AM.<ref name="Reopen" /><ref>Barnard, Anne.[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/24/nyregion/24grinch.html?scp=1&sq=%22The+Grinch%22&st=nyt "Broadway Now Brighter as 'The Grinch' Reopens"] ''The New York Times,'' November 24, 2007.</ref> Jujamcyn Theatres had planned to appeal the ruling, but dropped the case, allowing ''Grinch'' to play its entire run.
===Shows in previews affected by the strike=== * ''[[August: Osage County]]''—The official opening of this show (originally November 20) was postponed until December 4. * ''[[Is He Dead?]]''—The official opening of this show (originally November 29) was postponed until December 9. * ''[[The Farnsworth Invention]]''—The official opening of this show (originally November 14) was postponed until December 3. * ''[[The Seafarer (play)|The Seafarer]]''—The official opening of this show (originally November 15) was postponed until December 6. * ''[[The Little Mermaid (musical)|The Little Mermaid]]''—The official opening (originally December 6) was postponed until January 10, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=Little Mermaid Postpones Broadway Opening. |work=Playbill |date=November 20, 2007 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112944.html |accessdate=November 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122124342/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/112944.html |archivedate=November 22, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * ''[[The Homecoming]]''—The previews for this show, originally scheduled to begin November 23, were postponed until December 4.
===Broadway shows not affected=== * ''[[Xanadu (musical)|Xanadu]]'' * ''[[The Ritz (play)|The Ritz]]'' * ''[[Mauritius (play)|Mauritius]]'' * ''[[Cymbeline]]'' * ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' * ''[[The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee]]'' * ''[[Young Frankenstein (musical)|Young Frankenstein]]'' * ''[[Mary Poppins (musical)|Mary Poppins]]'' * ''The Third Annual Benefit Concert: A Cause For Celebration!'' (One-time only benefit)
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21717187/ "Broadway Goes Dark As Stagehands Strike," MSNBC, November 11, 2007] * [http://www.wnbc.com/news/14556483/detail.html?dl=mainclick "Broadway Stagehands Blame Producers For Strike, Cancellations," WNBC-TV, November 9, 2007] * [http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jFdKqhUfX5KSTTgYkSosl0pGiAfAD8SQJEE81 Michael Kuchwara, "Broadway Stagehands Going on Strike," ''Associated Press'', November 9, 2007]{{Dead link|date=September 2011}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071207213209/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21717188/ "Broadway Stagehands to Strike, Sources Say," MSNBC, November 10, 2007] * [https://archive.is/20130116015035/http://www.9news.com/life/entertainment/article.aspx?storyid=80723 "Stagehands Go on Strike, Shutting Down Most Broadway Shows," KUSA-TV, November 10, 2007] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071112075735/http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah7410.shtml "Show Won't Go On: Broadway Stagehands Go On Strike," Access Hollywood, November 10, 2007] * [https://archive.is/20130116062722/http://www.9news.com/life/entertainment/article.aspx?storyid=81849 "Stagehands, producers reach tentative agreement," KUSA-TV, November 28, 2007]
{{DEFAULTSORT:2007 Broadway Stagehand Strike}} [[Category:2007 labor disputes and strikes|Broadway Stagehand Strike, 2007]] [[Category:2007 in the United States|Broadway Stagehand Strike, 2007]] [[Category:Labor disputes in the United States]] [[Category:Broadway theatre]] [[Category:Musical theatre]] [[Category:International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] [[Category:Entertainment industry strikes]] [[Category:2007 in New York (state)|Broadway stagehand strike]]

page.title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain | image = 3_ninjas_high_noon_at_mega_mountain_poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | writer = Sean McNamara
Jeff Phillips | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Hulk Hogan]] * [[Loni Anderson]] * [[Victor Wong (actor born 1927)|Victor Wong]] * Mathew Botuchis * Michael J. O'Laskey II * [[imdbname:0736448|James Paul Roeske ll]] * [[Jim Varney]]}} | director = [[Sean McNamara (director)|Sean McNamara]] | producer = Arthur Leeds
[[Sang-ok Shin]] | cinematography = Blake T. Evans | editing = Annamaria Szanto | studio = Sheen Productions, inc.
Leeds Ben-Ami Productions, inc. | distributor = [[TriStar Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1998|04|10}} | runtime = 93 min. (94 min. in video release version) | language = English | country = United States | budget = | music = John Coda | gross = [[United States dollar|$]] 375,805 (U.S.) (sub-total) }} '''''3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain''''' is a 1998 American [[martial arts film]]. It is the fourth and final installment in the ''[[3 Ninjas (film series)|3 Ninjas]]'' franchise. The film starred only three of the original actors and was directed by [[Sean McNamara (director)|Sean McNamara]]. None of the child actors from the previous films returned for this installment. [[Victor Wong (actor born 1927)|Victor Wong]] is the only cast member to appear in all four films. It is also his final film before his death in 2001. It grossed [[United States dollar|US$]] $375,805 domestically,[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=3ninjas4.htm 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain (1998)] making it the least profitable of the franchise by far. It was filmed in [[Denver, Colorado]] at [[Elitch Gardens]]. ==Plot synopsis== During their summer vacation with their grandfather Mori, Rocky, Colt and Tum-Tum take a test on an [[obstacle course]] in pitch blackness. They passed the test. Later that night, he overhears Rocky and Colt planning on not returning the next year, due to getting older and he becomes depressed at this. Returning home, Tum-Tum is also becomes very depressed that his favorite TV Series Dave Dragon is going off the air soon and not even food can cheer him up, which confuses his mother Jessica. They meet a new neighbor, Amanda who accidentally sends her [[remote controlled]] helicopter into their house; she apologizes, and Jessica invites her to attend Tum-Tum's birthday party at Mega Mountain; an amusement park modeled after [[Six Flags]]. Once they get to the park, Rocky goes off on his own to be with his girlfriend Jennifer while Tum-Tum convinces Colt to go with him to a special live Dave Dragon show as his last performance. While the kids are enjoying themselves, a criminal named Mary Ann "Medusa" Rogers and her mens sneak in and commandeer the park, disabling many rides and shutting the place down to hold the patrons hostage in exchange for $10 Million from the park's owner Harry Jacobson. The boys and Amanda discover this and save Dave from being captured, as he seems to be the only viable threat to Medusa's plans. Amanda uses her [[laptop]] to try and override the controls, but Medusa's henchmen wrest control from her. Fearing they will interfere with her, she sends her idiot nephews out to capture them, but they are tricked by the boys and their access to an arsenal of small weapons and devices that Amanda possesses. Meanwhile, Dave sneaks into the command center, but is quickly discovered and captured. Finding video of Rocky and his girlfriend, she sends her second-in-command Lothar Zogg out to make sure they don't interfere. Medusa's nephews captures Jennifer and ties her to the bottom of a roller coaster loop. Medusa threatens to release the breaks and crush her if they don't cooperate, but Rocky goes to rescue her, But he gets attacked by Lothar. After a fight leading Rocky and Lothar to the top of the coaster, Rocky sends him off and he bounces out of the park and into the hands of the [[FBI]]. He then manages to free Jennifer before the roller coaster can crush them. Jacobson arrives via helicopter with the money to pay the ransom, but Amanda manages to destroy one of the bags with her helicopter. She is quickly captured by Medusa and they escape underground with the remainder of the money. Darkening the halls, the boys must overcome their weakness in the dark in order to rescue Amanda, who is tied to a bomb. They manage to free her, but they are unable to disarm the bomb, they attach it to an oxygen tank and with Dave's help, they bat off the top of the tank, sending it like a torpedo down Medusa's escape route. Alerted to the explosion, the FBI manages to capture Medusa, who resigns herself to defeat. Now hailed as heroes, the boys give the credit to Dave Dragon, hailing him as the real hero, to the press, the boys return home and assure Mori they will not be leaving their training. They also extend the offer to Amanda to come train with them the following year, and she gladly accepts. ==Cast== * Mathew Botuchis as Samuel "Rocky" Douglas * Michael O'Laskey II as Jeffrey "Colt" Douglas * [[imdbname:0736448|James Paul Roeske ll]] as Michael "Tum-Tum" Douglas * [[Emily Roeske]] as Little Girl * [[Lindsay Felton]] as Jennifer * [[Hulk Hogan]] as Dave Dragon * Chelsey Earlywine as Amanda * Alan McRae as Sam Douglas * [[Victor Wong (actor born 1927)|Victor Wong]] as Grandpa Mori Tanaka * [[Loni Anderson]] as Mary Ann "Medusa" Rogers * [[Jim Varney]] as Lothar Zogg * [[Kirk Baily]] as Carl * [[Brendan O'Brien (voice actor)|Brendan O'Brien]] as Zed * Travis McKenna as Buelow * Dwayne Carrington as C.J. * Pat Mahoney as Harry Jacobson ==Development== Filming began in 1996. Hulk Hogan, wrestling in [[World Championship Wrestling]] at the time, wore a wig for the film which resulted in him having a different hairstyle than his traditional bald look. As a result, he is seen in [[Halloween Havoc (1996)|Halloween Havoc 1996]] with a similar hairstyle as he had in the film. [[Elitch Gardens]], the park at which it was filmed, underwent a complete remodel, with all the signs for the park and rides being changed and renamed for the film. However, there are a few times when the real ones are seen in the background. ==Reception== The film had universally negative reviews and is generally considered to be the worst of the four in the series.{{cite news|title= MOVIE REVIEW : '3 Ninjas: High Noon' a Lively Action Adventure|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/10/entertainment/ca-37770|accessdate=2012-06-07}} It has a 0% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on six reviews.{{rottentomatoes|3_ninjas_high_noon_at_mega_mountain}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0118539}} {{3 Ninjas}} {{Sean McNamara}} {{DEFAULTSORT:3 Ninjas: High Noon At Mega Mountain}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1990s action films]] [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:1990s martial arts films]] [[Category:1990s sequel films]] [[Category:American action comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American martial arts films]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:Brookwell McNamara Entertainment films]] [[Category:3 Ninjas|High Noon at Mega Mountain]] [[Category:Films about brothers]] [[Category:Films about terrorism]] [[Category:Films directed by Sean McNamara]] [[Category:Films set in amusement parks]] [[Category:Martial arts comedy films]] [[Category:Ninja films]] [[Category:TriStar Pictures films]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Television episode | title = A Brown Thanksgiving | series = [[The Cleveland Show]] | image = File:Auntie-Mama-Cleveland-Show.png | caption = Auntie Momma arrives for Thanksgiving | season = 1 | episode = 7 | airdate = November 22, 2009 | production = 1APS09 | writer = Matt Murray | director = Chuck Klein and Matt Engstrom | guests = *[[Frances Callier]] as [[Cookie Brown]] *[[Craig Robinson (actor)|Craig Robinson]] as [[LeVar "Freight Train" Brown]]{{cite web|url=http://www.foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z1z25z1z8&ID=5342 |title=Fox Primetime |publisher=Fox Flash |date=2009-10-15 |accessdate=2012-11-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217092216/http://www.foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z1z25z1z8&ID=5342 |archivedate=2012-02-17 }} *[[Daryl Hall]] as himself *[[John Oates]] as himself *[[Kym Whitley]] as [[Auntie Momma]] | season_article = The Cleveland Show (season 1) | episode_list = List of The Cleveland Show episodes | season_list = | prev = [[Ladies' Night (The Cleveland Show)|Ladies' Night]] | next = [[From Bed to Worse (The Cleveland Show)|From Bed to Worse]] }} "'''A Brown Thanksgiving'''" is the seventh episode of ''[[The Cleveland Show]]''. The episode aired on November 22, 2009 on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in the United States. In this episode [[Cleveland Brown]] celebrates his first Thanksgiving with his new family, including his own parents and [[Donna Tubbs|Donna]]'s [[Auntie Momma]]. ==Plot== Cleveland celebrates [[Thanksgiving]] with his new family and his parents, Cookie and [[LeVar "Freight Train" Brown]]. Things become hostile until Donna's Auntie Momma arrives. Cleveland soon discovers that Auntie Momma is a [[trans woman]] after he sees her urinating while standing. He tries to tell Donna but refrains because she would be crushed to learn the truth. LeVar becomes smitten with Auntie Momma. Cleveland tries to tell his father about her but refrains, believing it is best that his father find out the hard way. Cleveland also learns from [[Rallo Tubbs|Rallo]] that he had known all along from sitting on Auntie Momma's lap. When LeVar and Auntie Momma come back down from having sex, they start teasing each other at dinner by subtly acting out their antics with the food. Cleveland becomes so disgusted and surprised that his father did not notice that he vomits all over the table. Meanwhile, [[Roberta Tubbs|Roberta]] decides to spend a romantic Thanksgiving together with Federline, but Donna refuses to let her. Only Auntie Momma's influence convinces Donna to let her leave. As the couple kiss by a river, Federline's car is stolen by two homeless men. They track the car to a mission where the poor (including [[Lester Krinklesac|Lester's]] family) are eating, being served by the Bear family. The homeless man who stole the car gives back the keys. Roberta notices the unity around her and realizes that family is more important. She returns home and apologizes to her mother. Later Cleveland confronts Auntie Momma and learns that she is actually Uncle Kevin, who was acting as a strong, female influence for Donna in place of her parents. He disguised his physical sex from LeVar. Since she sees that Cleveland will take good care of Donna, "Auntie Momma" decides that it is time to leave. Soon after, Cleveland tells his father the truth, causing him to vomit over the front porch before convincing him to reconcile with Cookie. ==Production== The episode also introduces Cleveland's father, Freight Train, who is portrayed by [[Craig Robinson (actor)|Craig Robinson]], Cleveland's mother, Cookie, who is portrayed by [[Frances Callier]], and Auntie Momma, who is portrayed by [[Kym Whitley]]. ==Reception== The episode was viewed by 6.32 million people being the third most viewed episode in its time slot.{{cite web|last=Gorman|first=Bill|title=TV Ratings Sunday: American Music Awards Rivals Football; Cold Case No Better At 9pm|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2009/11/23/tv-ratings-sunday-american-music-awards-rivals-football-cold-case-no-better-at-9pm/34292/|work=Zap2it|publisher=TV by the Numbers}} ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' graded the episode a C+, stating "It's not a big deal if these shows don't want to do complicated character development (Lord knows ''Family Guy'' didn't need it), but ''Cleveland Show'' has headed in this direction so often that I was a bit disappointed the episode didn't tie all of this together better".{{cite web|first=Todd|last=VanDerWerff|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/pranks-and-greensa-brown-thanksgivingjerome-is-the,35656/|title="Pranks and Greens"/"A Brown Thanksgiving"/"Jerome Is the New Black"/"My Morning Straitjacket"|work=The A.V. Club|date=2009-11-23|accessdate=2011-10-06}} "A Brown Thanksgiving" came under fire from the [[Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]] (GLAAD) after Bil Browning of the LGBT blog [[The Bilerico Project]] expressed shock at the organization's lack of response to the portrayal of a [[transgender]] character.{{cite web | last = Browning | first = Bil | title = The Cleveland Show goes transphobic: GLAAD goes silent | work = The Bilerico Project | date = 2009-11-29 | url = http://www.bilerico.com/2009/11/the_cleveland_show_goes_transphobic_glaad_goes_sil.php | accessdate = 2010-06-26}} GLAAD released a statement that it had already been in contact with Fox and the show's producers as "part of an ongoing discussion that GLAAD is having with Fox regarding consistent homophobic and transphobic jokes in some of its animated programming. The problematic transgender episode Bilerico points to is one of several instances that the Entertainment Team will be discussing with them, as well as advocating for more fair LGBT inclusion."{{Cite press release | title = GLAAD Responds to Bilerico and The Cleveland Show | publisher = Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation | date = 2009-11-30 | url = http://glaadblog.org/2009/11/30/glaad-responds-to-bilerico-and-the-cleveland-show/ | accessdate = 2010-06-26}} Speaking with LGBT media website [[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]] in January 2010, series creator [[Seth MacFarlane]] said "It always distresses me when I hear that the gay community is upset with us, because that's one group of people I hope would know we're on their side."{{cite web|author=Hartinger, Brent |title=Is Family Guy's Seth MacFarlane a Complete Idiot? |publisher=AfterElton.com |date=2010-05-10 |url=http://www.afterelton.com/TV/2010/5/seth-macfarlane-complete-idiot |accessdate=2010-05-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100513151543/http://www.afterelton.com/TV/2010/5/seth-macfarlane-complete-idiot |archivedate=13 May 2010 |deadurl=yes }} However, in May 2010 MacFarlane again drew GLAAD's ire when, in the ''Family Guy'' episode "[[Quagmire's Dad]]", another character ([[Brian Griffin|Brian]]) also reacts to learning he had sex with a trans woman by vomiting for close to 30 seconds.{{cite web| author = Rosales, Jonathan| title = GLAAD Shares Community Concerns About Last Night's Family Guy| publisher = [[Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]] | date = 2010-05-10| url = http://glaadblog.org/2010/05/10/glaad-shares-community-concerns-about-last-nights-family-guy/| accessdate = 2010-05-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100514164533/http://glaadblog.org/2010/05/10/glaad-shares-community-concerns-about-last-nights-family-guy/| archivedate= 14 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} ==Cultural references== * The dish detergent Cascade was mentioned twice. * Auntie Mamma compliments Cleveland's mustache by saying "mustache all, putting [[Wilt Chamberlain]] to shame!", referencing Wilt Chamberlain's mustache. She also references [[Wilt Chamberlain]]'s sexual exploits, more specifically the 20,000 women claim when she says that she should know, because she was number 8,433 and 11,760. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|The_Cleveland_Show/Season_1#A Brown Thanksgiving|
"A Brown Thanksgiving"}} *{{imdb episode|id=tt1535085/}} *{{tv.com episode|the-cleveland-show/a-brown-thanksgiving-1301956}} {{Sequence | prev= [[Ladies' Night (The Cleveland Show)|Ladies' Night]]| list=[[The Cleveland Show (season 1)]] | next=[[From Bed to Worse (The Cleveland Show)|From Bed to Worse]] }} {{The Cleveland Show episodes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brown Thanksgiving}} [[Category:2009 American television episodes]] [[Category:The Cleveland Show (season 1) episodes]] [[Category:American LGBT-related television episodes]] [[Category:Thanksgiving television episodes]] [[Category:Transgender in television]] [[it:Episodi di The Cleveland Show (prima stagione)#Il giorno del ringraziamento]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=[[Armitron]], a US watch company}} [[File:TOMY Armatron 3.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|An Armatron]] [[File:TOMY Armatron 5.jpg|thumb|upright=.7|Hand detail]]
The '''Armatron''' was a toy robot made by [[TOMY]] and distributed by [[Radio Shack]] in the United States since 1984.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hawkins |first=William J. |date=1984-03-01 |title=What's new in Electronics |url=https://books.google.de/books?id=rAAAAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA114&dq=armatron&hl=de&pg=PA114#v=onepage&q=armatron&f=false |magazine=Popular Science}}</ref> It consisted of a [[Crane (machine)|crane]]-like arm with two attached [[joystick]]s which could be manipulated to pick up small objects. It was essentially similar to industrial robots of the 1980s, though it was strictly user-controlled, with no automation built in.
The Armatron existed in both the original fixed version and a mobile version with a wired remote. It included an "energy level" indicator (actually a countdown timer) and a series of objects such as boxes and spheres designed to be manipulated by the arm. Models with alternate decals or coloring were marketed under slightly different names, including the Super Armatron and the Armatron II.
The original Radio Shack Armatron also came with a module pack of items the Armatron was able to lift and move. The Module pack consisted of a Flat Module, with 2 cones and 2 globes as well as a "closed module" which also had impressions of the cones and globes on it as a second platform for the objects to be moved to and from.
Movement of the arm was almost purely mechanical; the only electronic component was the motor. The two joysticks selectively engaged or disengaged gears on a set of rotating drums to control the arm's movement.
==See also== *[[Waldo (short story)|Waldo (Heinlein)]] *[[Remote manipulator|Waldo]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Armatron}} *[http://users.netonecom.net/~swordman/Photos/ForSale/Armatron.jpg Photograph of an Armatron] *[http://www.inthe80s.com/toys/armatron.shtml Photograph of an Armatron] *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/marc-julien_objois/sets/72157604678979867/ Photo set of an Armatron] *[http://support.radioshack.com/support_games/doc25/25534.htm Part list for the Super Armatron] *[http://www.theoldrobots.com/armatron2.html Armatron color/model variants] *[http://www.jeff-z.com/pinball/toys/armatron/armatron.html Patent drawings and other detailed info] *[http://www.starborneworks.com/?p=22 Description of internal components]
[[Category:Toy robots]] [[Category:Takara Tomy]] [[Category:1980s toys]] [[Category:Electronic toys]]
{{toy-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox circus |name=Big Apple Circus |image=[[Image:Big Apple Circus Logo.png]] |caption= |country=United States |founder=[[Paul Binder]] and Michael Christensen |year=1977 |operator=Big Apple Circus |ringmaster=Tyron “Ty” McFarlan |traveling=Yes |website={{URL|bigapplecircus.com}} }} {{infobox organization |formation={{start date and age|1977|03}} |purpose=To spread joy and wonder of a classical circus |region=[[United States]] |staff=60+ |key_people={{Unbulleted list|[[Peter Grauer]] ([[Chairman]])|Will Maitland Weiss (Executive Director)}} |location=[[Brooklyn, New York]] }} The '''Big Apple Circus''' is a [[circus]] based in New York City. Opened in 1977, later becoming a [[nonprofit organization]], it became a tourist attraction.<ref name="bigac">{{cite web|url=http://www.circusesandsideshows.com/circuses/bigapplecircus.html|title=Big Apple Circus|publisher=Circuses and side shows|work=Circuses and side shows|accessdate=2016-10-10}}</ref> The circus has been known for its community outreach programs, including [[Clown Care]], as well as its humane treatment of animals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/11/07/how-the-circus-got-a-social-conscience.html|title=How the Circus Got a Social Conscience|last=Jones|first=Justin|date=2014-11-07|website=The Daily Beast|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref> Big Apple Circus filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] in November 2016 and exited bankruptcy in February 2017 after its assets were bought by Compass Partners.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/11/21/big-apple-circus-files-for-bankruptcy.html|title=That's all folks? Big Apple Circus files for bankruptcy|last=Whitten|first=Sarah|date=2016-11-21|website=CNBC|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/big-apple-circus-springs-new-owner/|title=Big Apple Circus springs back to life|last=|first=|date=|work=CBS News|access-date=2017-03-06|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-apple-circus-finds-buyer-in-compass-partners-1486644176|title=Big Apple Circus Finds Buyer in Compass Partners|last=Randles|first=Jonathan|date=2017-02-09|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-03-23|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> The Circus was renewed in October 2017 for its 40th anniversary season.<ref name=":2" />
== History ==
=== The 1970s === Gregory Fedin and his then wife Nina Krasavina, both born and trained in Russia, started a circus school to train future "first" generation circus performers. They started the small school in a lower [[Manhattan loft]].<ref name="bigac" />
The circus couple worked with [[Paul Binder]] and Michael Christensen to develop the Big Apple Circus following the European style "one ring" circus. In 1977, they located and secured an open ground area, in [[Battery Park]], where the Big Apple Circus debuted. Headlining the early shows was a single [[trapeze]], a dog act, [[Tightrope walking|tight rope walking]], [[Juggling|jugglers]] and clowns, double trapeze artists, and a host of other performers.<ref name="bigac" />
During 1978, the circus moved from [[Manhattan]]. By 1979, two circus arts schools had been opened with money raised from the circus shows.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
=== The 1980s === The Big Apple Circus began the 1980s with a special holiday celebration in honor of the circus and its staff. In 1981, the circus began performing at [[Damrosch Park]] of [[Lincoln Center]] for the first time, continuing until 2015. In 1982, the circus won a silver medal at a circus performing competition held in [[Paris, France|Paris]].<ref name="bigac" />
The circus began to arrange tours across [[New England]] in 1983. They also received an [[Obie award]] that year.<ref name="bigac" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/arts/big-apple-circus-pitches-a-tent-in-lincoln-center.html|title=BIG APPLE CIRCUS PITCHES A TENT IN LINCOLN CENTER|date=4 December 1981|work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
By 1984, the New York School for Circus Arts/Big Apple Circus relocated to [[East Harlem]]. The New York School for Circus Arts, in conjunction with [[New York City Public Schools]] and ArtsConnection, established the Young Talent Circus Training Program. The circus program mission was to teach talented children of diverse economic communities circus arts. One of the goals was to nurture and develop talent into potential circus performers. A core group of young circus "talent" participated in a circus competition resulting in a "Gold Medal" award. Three years later, another group from the pre-professional circus program (located in the Harbor School for the Performing Arts in East Harlem) would compete in the II Rampe International Circus School Competition in [[Monte Carlo, Monaco]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In 1985, the [[Boston Pops]] teamed up with Big Apple Circus for what was touted as an extraordinary collaboration and live performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://openvault.wgbh.org/catalog/V_22C386AF6EDB42F9979C8539CB420E29|title=Evening at Pops; Pops Joins The Circus|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> Also in 1985 and for the next few years, BAC performers appeared as guest artists with the [[Metropolitan Opera]] at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/27/arts/for-big-apple-aerialist-a-lifetime-in-the-circus.html|title=FOR BIG APPLE AERIALIST, A LIFETIME IN THE CIRCUS|date=27 December 1985|work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
Then, in 1986, one of the biggest steps in the institution's history was taken, when the circus opened the [[Clown Care]] unit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.simplycircus.com/sites/default/files/4_3.pdf|title=Clown as interpreters of emotions|last=Dionigi|first=Alberto|date=|website=simplycircus.com|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018215310/http://www.simplycircus.com/sites/default/files/4_3.pdf|archivedate=2016-10-18|df=}}</ref>
The circus celebrated its tenth anniversary in 1987 with a big celebration, as well as a new tent and seating system added. Topping the celebrations was a prestigious silver crown, which the circus won at the International Circus School competition in [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]], where six of the circus' [[Acrobatics|acrobats]]/[[Juggling|jugglers]] showcased their talent.<ref name="bigac" />
During 1988 season, the Big Apple Circus participated in the first circus collaboration between China and the United States in history. "''East Meets West''" debut at the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]] [[Damrosch Park]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In 1989, [[NYNEX]] started to sponsor metropolitan New York tours to residents of the area and tourists as well. The tour included a trip to the Big Apple Circus' grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.713-tickets.com/tickets/family/big-apple-circus-celebrate!-tickets/|title=Big Apple Circus - Celebrate! Tickets - Damrosch Park- Lincoln Center - Family Shows, Attractions and Fun Kids Events!|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> The circus and some of its performers were showcased in the [[Woody Allen]] movie ''[[Alice (1990 film)|Alice]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/event/the-big-apple-circus-november-3-1989-75121487#mia-farrow-woody-allen-and-their-children-during-the-big-apple-circus-picture-id106268660|title=The Big Apple Circus - November 3, 1989 Photos and Images - Getty Images|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.woodyallenmovies.com/movies/anniehallsoundtrack.php|title=Annie Hall Movie Soundtrack|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
=== The 1990s === In 1991, the circus appeared in a [[Hollywood]] film commemorating its 15th anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2331105/|title=The Big Apple Circus|date=9 September 1991|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016|via=IMDb}}</ref>
By 1996, there was increased interest in Big Apple Circus and its performers in cities outside the New York/[[New England]] area. This was in part due to the circus' exposure in the Woody Allen film. In 1996, BAC traveled to both [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] and [[Columbus, Ohio]]. Michael Christensen received two more awards, including one named after [[Red Skelton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.mcall.com/1993-02-01/news/2904913_1_youth-group-clown-care-unit-new-show|title=Bangor Man Clowns For Living `Mr. Stubs' Says His Craft Also Teaches, Is Not Mere Folly|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In 1991, Big Apple Circus' performers participated in a collaboration between American and Russian circus performers.<ref name="bigac" />
In 1993, the circus set a new attendance record. A new tent was purchased, and Michael Christensen was given a Parenting Achievement award by [[Parents (magazine)|''Parents'' magazine]], to recognize his work with Clown Care.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nymetroparents.com/article/For-hospitalized-childrenThe-Real-White-Glove-Treatment|title=For hospitalized children, The Real White Glove Treatment|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
Gary Dunning became the Big Circus' executive director in 1994. In addition, the coffee brand [[Chock full o'Nuts]] began sponsoring the circus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://circusfans.org/news_detail.php?news_id=2690|title=CFA News Detail|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebrityseries.org/CS_aboutus/gdunning.htm|title=Gary Dunning - President and Executive Director - bio|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
[[Peter Grauer|Peter T. Grauer]] became the circus' Chairman in 1995, replacing Patricia Rosenwald.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=73375&privcapId=160210|title=Peter T. Grauer: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In 1996, the circus' Art in Education program began to work in different grade schools. [[Clown Care]] continued to develop, opening chapters in [[Washington, D.C.]] and in [[Connecticut]].<ref>[http://schools.nyc.gov/offices/teachlearn/arts/files/ACES_June2016.pdf schools.nyc.gov, New York City Department of Education, NYC.gov]</ref>
1997 saw new attendance records set, as an estimated 170,000 people went to see the circus' "Medicine Show" production over a total of 114 New York City performances. Furthermore, Clown Care completed 150,000 hospital visits in one year for the first time in the program's history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/nydn-features/big-apple-circus-fun-core-sick-tired-old-routine-friend-medicine-show-cure-article-1.744881|title=Big Apple Circus: Fun to its Very Core Sick and Tired of the Same Old Routine, Friend? 'Medicine Show' a Sure Cure|last=Schultz|first=Paul|date=1996-11-01|website=New York Daily News|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
During 1998, the circus was able to break attendance records again, as it celebrated twenty years of operation with engagements at New York's [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]] and in [[Boston]]. The Boston engagement was particularly pleasant for the circus' performers, as it was one of the longest stays in that city that they had ever experienced. [[TJ Maxx]] began to sponsor Big Apple Circus appearances in [[Chicago]] and in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] by bringing the "Circus of the Senses" to those cities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nytheatre-wire.com/circus.htm|title=What's Hot|last=Gener|first=Randy|date=1999-12-01|website=www.nytheatre-wire.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://business.highbeam.com/53/article-1G1-19907071/big-apple-circus-augment-season-bigname-presenting|title=Big Apple Circus to augment season with big-name presenting sponsors. (Bristol Meyers-Squibb, Newsweek Magazine, Chase Manhattan Bank, Toyota, TJ Maxx stores and Northwest Airlines) - HighBeam Business: Arrive Prepared|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In 1999, co-founder Michael Christensen was inducted into [[Miami, Florida|Miami]]'s Ambassador David A. Walters pediatric Hall of Fame, for his "contributions to pediatrics" by way of the circus and its different programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mchf.org/hall-of-fame|title=Hall of Fame - Miami Children's Health Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
=== The 2000s === Once again in 1999, "Circus of the Senses" attracted a large number of special children, with 9,000 kids participating. The circus dropped plans for a second unit that was to play in theaters after less than successful financial results during a trial run.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.necn.com/entertainment/the-scene/Circus-of-the-Senses-297741801.html|title=Circus of the Senses|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bostoncentral.com/events/big-apple-circus-boston/p40494.php|title=Big Apple Circus: The Grand Tour - Boston Central|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> Additionally, the Big Apple Circus became a [[501(c)(3) nonprofit organization|501(c)3 non-profit organization]] in March 2000.
In 2001, the circus' best known performer, "Grandma" the clown (played by [[Barry Lubin]]), inducted into the [[International Clown Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barrylubin.com/|title=Barry Lubin|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.circopedia.org/index.php/Barry_Lubin|title=Barry Lubin - Circopedia|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> A new seating system was installed in the circus big top, and, after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], the circus opened its "Dreams of a City" show, which was dedicated to the [[New York City|City of New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesledger.com/stories/2003/15/20030410-archive44.html|title=Big Apple Circus has big ‘Dreams’ for boro|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>Clowns: In Conversation with Modern Masters, By Ezra LeBank, David Bridel, page 192</ref>
[[Mayor of New York City|New York City Mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]] proclaimed November 1, 2002, as "Big Apple Circus Day".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/things-to-do/big-apple-circus-day-of-celebration|title=Big Apple Circus Day of Celebration|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discoveringmenurseryschool.com/2011/05/big-apple-circus-day/|title=Big Apple Circus Day!!|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> The circus celebrated its 25th anniversary with a documentary film about the creation and production of that year's show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/4278532-big-apple-circus-25th-anniversary-book|title=Big Apple Circus 25th Anniversary Book|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarloafpac.org/big-apple-circus-to-perform-on-june-26th/|title=Big Apple Circus to Perform on June 26th! - Sugar Loaf Performing Arts Center|date=26 May 2015|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In "Carnevale!", actors and circus performers Pedro Carrillo and Alesya Gulevich entered the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] when, in 2003, they set records, at the same moment, in their different specialties: Carrillo [[Skipping rope|skipped a rope]] on the [[Tightrope walking|high wire]] 1,323 times in a row, and Gulevich twirled 99 [[Hula hoop|hula hoops]] at the same time.<ref><[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05EFD71E31F93BA15753C1A9659C8B63 NY Times, PUBLIC LIVES; Creating the Spirit of Carnival in a Tent, By GLENN COLLINS, OCT. 28, 2003]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/20040408/News/304089954|title=Big Apple Circus is gasp-worthy|last=correspondent|first=David Brooks Andrews, Standard-Times|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2004/04/06/big_apple_circus_is_polished/|title=Big Apple Circus is polished - The Boston Globe|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> Another show, "Circus to Go," allowed Big Apple Circus to reach new communities, specifically in Western states.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-27/big-apple-circus-folds-its-tent-as-wall-street-support-drops-off|title=Big Apple Circus Folds Its Tent as Wall Street Support Drops Off|last=hgoldman77|first=Henry Goldman|date=27 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref>
In 2004, a TV documentary created by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] on the circus received an [[Emmy]] award in the "Outstanding Entertainment in Programming Single Program" category.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
Then, in 2005, [[Barry Lubin]] helped produce a show entitled "Grandma Goes To Hollywood."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtUilo_oHcc|title=big apple circus commercial|last=elleisinny|first=|date=8 July 2008|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>Tall Tales of A Short Clown By Barry Lubin</ref>
On December 2, 2008, [[Britney Spears]] performed her hits [[Circus (Britney Spears song)|Circus]] & [[Womanizer (song)|Womanizer]] in a televised promotion concert on [[Good Morning America]] at the Big Apple Circus. The Big Apple Circus went on to become the opening act on her phenomenally successful [[The Circus Starring Britney Spears]] world tour.<ref name="NYP">{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/three_ring_drama_RbfSorrYpDUBCdKBybXNXO|title=A three-ring drama: Big Apple Circus juggles expenses to survive recession|last=EARLE-LEVINE|first=JULIE|date=November 13, 2010|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=2010-12-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eADzF5q2avs|title=Britney Spears- Big Apple Circus Entrance Performance (Live @ Sydney Acer Arena)|last=Victoria Cunningham|first=|date=19 July 2011|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref>
In the 2008-2009 season, filming of a [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] documentary occurred. The documentary, titled "Circus", portrays the lives of not only the performers, but the crew as well. On November 2, 2010, [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] began to air the six-part event, told in chronological order.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/14/nyregion/14circus.html|title=Jake and Marty LaSalle, Twin Brothers, End Circus Act|last=MASLIN NIR|first=SARAH|date=November 12, 2010|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2010-12-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/show/circus/|title=Watch Full Episodes Online of Circus on PBS|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
=== The 2010s === The 2010-2011 season show was titled "Dance On", while the 2011-2012 season show was themed "Dream Big" and was the farewell tour for the clown character ''Grandma'', played by [[Barry Lubin|Barry Lublin]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/12/17/143886786/grandma-the-clown-is-leaving-the-tent|title=Grandma The Clown Is Leaving The Tent|last=Simon|first=Scott|date=2011-12-11|website=NPR|publisher=National Public Radio|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/big-apple-circus-dance/|title=The Big Apple Circus: Dance On!|last=|first=|date=|website=Broadway.com|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In 2014, the ''Big Apple Circus Metamorphosis'' was released to video.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/big_apple_circus_metamorphosis/|title=Big Apple Circus Metamorphosis|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=55PMAsyTi4E|title=Big Apple Circus METAMORPHOSIS Lincoln Center|last=Big Apple Circus|first=|date=8 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==== Bankruptcy ==== In July 2016, it was announced that for the first time since 1981 the circus would not run for the 2016 holiday season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/overwhelming-deficit-force-big-apple-circus-to-cancel-2016-2017-tour|title=Big Apple Circus Cancels 2016-2017 Season {{!}} Playbill|website=Playbill|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref> The Circus set a fundraising goal for $2 million in 2016 in an effort to maintain operations, but only half of the funds needed were raised.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/27/nyregion/big-apple-circus.html|title=With No Heroes in Sight, the Big Apple Circus Will Fold Its Tent|date=27 July 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/05/nyregion/can-the-big-apple-circus-be-saved.html|title=Can the Big Apple Circus Be Saved?|date=3 June 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/overwhelming-deficit-force-big-apple-circus-to-cancel-2016-2017-tour|title=Big Apple Circus Cancels 2016-2017 Season|last=|first=|date=|website=Playbill|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> The circus filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] on November 11, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/15/nyregion/big-apple-circus.html|title=The Last Days of the Big Apple Circus|last=Leland|first=John|date=2016-12-15|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-apple-circus-gets-buyers-expressions-of-interest-1479851958|title=Big Apple Circus Gets Buyers’ Expressions of Interest|last=Randles|first=Jonathan|date=2016-11-22|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bigapplecircus.org/|title=Big Apple Circus|date=2017-01-06|access-date=2017-01-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106211920/http://www.bigapplecircus.org/|archivedate=2017-01-06|df=}}</ref> It was announced on January 13, 2017 that they will auction off their assets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-apple-circus-hopes-bankruptcy-auction-leads-to-a-second-act-1482875534|title=Big Apple Circus Hopes Bankruptcy Auction Leads to a Second Act|last=Randles|first=Jonathan|date=2016-12-27|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/big-apple-circus-is-selling-its-assets|title=Big Apple Circus Is Selling Its Assets {{!}} Playbill|website=Playbill|access-date=2017-01-14}}</ref> On February 14, 2017, Big Apple Circus announced that the U.S. Bankruptcy Court had approved the sale of their assets to Big Top Works, an affiliate of Compass Partners, for $1.3 million.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/court-approves-deal-save-big-apple-circus-article-1.2972777|title=Court approves deal to save Big Apple Circus|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2017-03-06|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-apple-circus-bankruptcy-sale-gets-green-light-1487102352|title=Big Apple Circus Bankruptcy Sale Gets Green Light|last=Randles|first=Jonathan|date=2017-02-14|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-03-06|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> As part of the sale, the circus will be renewed for its 40th anniversary season and some community programs will continue.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/arts/big-apple-circus-sold-to-the-highest-bidder-will-return-this-fall.html|title=Big Apple Circus, Sold to the Highest Bidder, Will Return This Fall|last=Barone|first=Joshua|date=2017-02-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-06|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
==== Post-Bankruptcy ==== On March 21, 2017, Big Apple Circus announced that renowned acrobat [[Nik Wallenda]] will be the headline act in the 40th anniversary season at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center's]] [[Damrosch Park]] in [[New York City]] from October 26, 2017 to January 7, 2018. Additionally, the circus announced that following the New York performances, a national tour will take place.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nik-wallenda-to-join-the-big-apple-circus-1490096100|title=Nik Wallenda to Join the Big Apple Circus|last=Passy|first=Charles|date=2017-03-21|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-03-23|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
It was announced in May 2017 that "Grandma the Clown", played by [[Barry Lubin]], would return for the 40th anniversary season and that the new ringmaster will be Tyron McFarlan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/grandma-clown-return-big-apple-circus-5-years-article-1.3151532|title=EXCLUSIVE: Grandma the Clown to return to Big Apple Circus|last=Scotti|first=Ariel|date=2017-05-09|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Big Apple Circus Welcomes New Ringmaster, Return of Grandma|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Big-Apple-Circus-Welcomes-New-Ringmaster-Return-of-Grandma-20170518|website=BroadwayWorld.com|language=en|date=May 18, 2017}}</ref>
On January 23, 2018, Lubin announced that he would resign from the circus due to sexual misconduct with an underage teen from 2004.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/barry-lubin-grandma-the-clown-resigns-sexual-misconduct-big-apple-circus/|title="Grandma the Clown" admits to pressuring teen to take pornographic photos, resigns from circus: report|last=Brito|first=Christopher|date=2018-01-24|work=CBS News|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en}}</ref>
In September, 2018, Big Apple Circus announced that [[Bindlestiff Family Cirkus]] owner, Stephanie Monseu is the new Ringmistress for Big Apple Circus. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/bigapplecircus/photos/a.161579816058/10155408830271059/?type=1&theater|title=Big Apple Circus|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://travsd.wordpress.com/2018/09/14/big-apple-circus-gets-a-lady-ringmaster/|title=Big Apple Circus Gets a Lady Ringmaster|date=2018-09-14|work=(Travalanche)|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://circustalk.com/news/the-wonder-women-of-big-apple-circuses-next-season/|title=The Big Apple Circus–2018/2019 Season’s Wonder Women - CircusTalk|work=CircusTalk|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Other Programs == Following the circus' emergence from bankruptcy in 2017, community programs "for low income children and those with special needs as well as other programs geared toward helping the community" will continue.<ref name=":4" />
=== Circus of the Senses === Started in 1987, Circus of the Senses is a circus performance specifically geared towards children and adults with vision or hearing impairments, as well as special needs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bigapplecircus.org/circus-of-the-senses|title=Circus of the Senses|last=|first=|date=|website=Big Apple Circus|publisher=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|access-date=2017-01-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206001654/http://bigapplecircus.org/circus-of-the-senses|archivedate=2015-02-06|df=}}</ref> Sign language interpreters and sound augmentation for deaf patrons allow the audience to experience the circus as never before. In 1999, over 6,000 children took advantage of these performances. The program is run by the Big Apple Circus.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bigapplecircus.com/about/bac-gives-back/|title=BAC Gives Back|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
=== Embracing Autism Performances === Started in 2017, upon the Circus entering new ownership after bankruptcy, Embracing Autism Performances have a reduced running time, as well as sensory adaptations.<ref name=":5" />
=== Former Programs ===
==== Clown Care ==== Founded in 1986, the Big Apple Circus Clown Care program is composed of over 80 professional clowns, trained extensively in hospital procedures, circus skills, and improvisation, who make rounds as 'clown doctors' at various pediatric hospitals around the U.S. It is estimated that the clowns make more than 225,000 visits to children every year "in both inpatient and outpatient units, including intensive care, emergency room, physical therapy, bone marrow transplant, pediatric AIDS, and hematology/oncology."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nicklauschildrens.org/news-and-events/press-releases/big-apple-circus-clown-care-celebrates-15-years|title=Big Apple Circus Clown Care® Celebrates 15 Years of Bringing Smiles to Hospitalized Children at Nick - Nicklaus Children's Hospital|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rednoses.eu/news/interview-michael-christensen/#.WAU1KyRmVLI|title=RED NOSES Clowndoctors: Interview Michael Christensen|publisher=|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bigapplecircus.org/clown-care|title=Clown Care|last=|first=|date=|website=Big Apple Circus|publisher=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|access-date=2017-01-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206001659/http://bigapplecircus.org/clown-care|archivedate=2015-02-06|df=}}</ref> The continuation of Clown Care programs were not included in Big Apple Circus' bankruptcy sale and have since been taken over by various local organizations.
==== Circus After School ==== Big Apple Circus' Circus After School program gives opportunities for "at-risk youth to develop life-enhancing skills such as teamwork, commitment, and responsible risk-taking through a structured program of learning and performing the circus arts."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bigapplecircus.org/circus-after-school|title=Circus After School|last=|first=|date=|website=Big Apple Circus|publisher=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|access-date=2017-01-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206001644/http://bigapplecircus.org/circus-after-school|archivedate=2015-02-06|df=}}</ref> Since emerging from bankruptcy, it is no longer a program of the Circus.<ref name=":5" />
==== Vaudeville Caravan ==== Founded in 2001 as a spin-off of the Clown Care program, the Vaudeville Caravan brings clowns to nursing homes.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://bigapplecircus.org/community-programs|title=Community Programs|last=|first=|date=|website=Big Apple Circus|publisher=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|access-date=2017-01-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206001705/http://bigapplecircus.org/community-programs|archivedate=2015-02-06|df=}}</ref> Since emerging from bankruptcy, it is no longer a program of the Circus.<ref name=":5" />
==== Circus for All ==== The Circus for All program provides Big Apple Circus tickets to low-income and disadvantaged children, families, and elderly.<ref name=":1" /> Since emerging from bankruptcy, it is no longer a program of the Circus.<ref name=":5" />
==== Circopedia ==== Started in October 2008, Circopedia is an online circus encyclopedia. It is no longer managed by the Circus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.circopedia.org/Circopedia:About|title=About Circopedia|last=|first=|date=|website=Circopedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref>

{{for|the English professional boxer|Billy Bird}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = Billie Bird.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Berniece Bird Stowell{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} | birth_date = {{birth date|1908|02|28}} | birth_place = [[Pocatello, Idaho]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2002|11|27|1908|02|28}} | death_place = [[Granada Hills, Los Angeles|Granada Hills]], [[California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]], [[California]] | occupation = Actress, comedian | yearsactive = 1951–1997 | spouse = Edwin Sellen (?–1966; his death; 3 children) }} '''Billie Sellen''' (February 28, 1908 – November 27, 2002), better known professionally as '''Billie Bird''', was an American actress and [[comedian]].{{cite web|url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2ba8773aa9|title=Billie Bird|work=BFI}} ==Early life== Born in [[Pocatello, Idaho]], Bird was discovered at the age of eight while living at an orphanage. As a child, she worked in [[vaudeville]], and later in [[theater]]/[[cabaret]] before moving on to [[television]] and [[film]]s.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/dec/06/local/me-passings6.2|title=Billie Bird, 94; Actress Had Character Roles in Movies, on TV|date=2002-12-06|publisher=''The LA Times''|accessdate=2009-02-03}} ==Career== She is credited with an appearance in a 1921 film ''Grass Widowers'', but it is not clear if this is accurate. Otherwise, she broke into films in 1950, later making a brief, uncredited appearance in ''[[The Odd Couple (film)|The Odd Couple]]'' as a [[maid|chambermaid]]. Her only line was "Goodnight", which was said to Felix Ungar, who responded, "Goodbye." Bird often was cast by director [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]] and appeared in many of his 1980 and 1990s films, such as ''[[Sixteen Candles]]'', ''[[Home Alone]]'', and ''[[Dennis the Menace (film)|Dennis the Menace]]'', the latter two of which both paired her with veteran Hughes actor [[Bill Erwin]] playing her husband. She also starred as Mrs. Lois Feldman in ''[[Police Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol|Police Academy 4]]''. Her last film appearance was in 1995's ''[[Jury Duty (film)|Jury Duty]]'', with [[Pauly Shore]]. In addition to films, Bird made numerous appearances on various television series, including roles on ''Silver Spoons'', ''[[Ironside (TV series)|Ironside]]'', ''[[Eight Is Enough]]'', ''[[The Facts of Life (TV series)|The Facts of Life]]'', ''[[Who's the Boss?]]'', and ''[[Knots Landing]]''. She was also a regular cast member on the sitcoms ''[[It Takes Two (U.S. TV series)|It Takes Two]]'' in 1982 and ''[[Benson (TV series)|Benson]]'' from 1984 to 1986. In 1988, she joined the cast of ''[[Dear John (U.S. TV series)|Dear John]]'' starring [[Judd Hirsch]]. Her last acting role was a brief appearance in 1997 on an episode of the sitcom ''[[George and Leo]]'', which starred [[Bob Newhart]] and Bird's former co-star, Hirsch. ==Personal life== Bird was married to Edwin Sellen until his death in 1966; they had three children. ==Death== Bird died on November 27, 2002 in [[Granada Hills, Los Angeles|Granada Hills]], [[California]] at the age of 94 after a long battle with [[Alzheimer's disease]]. She is buried in the [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Glendale, California]]. ==Selected filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1951 | ''[[The Mating Season (film)|The Mating Season]]'' | Mugsy | 1953 "Somebody Loves Me" |- | 1954 | ''[[Woman's World (film)|Woman's World]]'' | Woman in Bargain Basement | Uncredited
Alternative title: ''A Woman's World'' |- | 1959 | ''[[Born to Be Loved]]'' | Drunk's wife | |- | 1960 | ''[[Too Soon to Love]]'' | Mrs. Jefferson | Alternative title: ''Teenage Lovers'' |- | 1967 | ''[[Barefoot in the Park (film)|Barefoot in the Park]]'' | Drunken neighbor | Uncredited |- | 1968 | ''[[The Odd Couple (film)|The Odd Couple]]'' | Chambermaid | Uncredited |- | 1970 | ''[[Getting Straight]]'' | Landlady | |- | 1982 | ''[[Young Doctors in Love]]'' | Mrs. Greschler the Flower Lady | |- | 1983 | ''[[Max Dugan Returns]]'' | Older Woman | |- | 1984 | ''[[Sixteen Candles]]'' | Dorothy Baker (Grandmother) | |- | 1986 | ''[[One Crazy Summer]]'' | Grandma | |- | 1987 | ''[[Police Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol|Police Academy 4]]'' | Mrs. Lois Feldman | |- | 1988 | ''[[Ernest Saves Christmas]]'' | Mary Morrissey | |- | 1989 | ''[[That's Adequate]]'' | Old Lillian Darling | |- | 1990 | ''[[Home Alone]]'' | Irene (woman in airport) | |- | 1990 | ''[[The End of Innocence (film)|The End of Innocence]]'' | Mrs. Yabledablov | |- | 1993 | ''[[Dennis the Menace (film)|Dennis the Menace]]'' | Edith Butterwell | |- | 1995 | ''[[Jury Duty (film)|Jury Duty]]'' | Rose | |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Television |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1958 | ''[[Letter to Loretta]]'' | Mrs. Shubb | 1 episode |- | 1971 | ''[[Adam-12]]'' | Winnie Goodrich | 1 episode |- | 1973 | ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' | Old Woman | 1 episode |- | 1974 | ''[[Apple's Way]]'' | Lillian | 1 episode |- | 1976–

Shirley | 2 episodes |- | 1982 | ''[[House Calls (TV series)|House Calls]]'' | | 1 episode |- | 1982 | ''[[It Takes Two (sitcom)|It Takes Two]]'' | Mama | 22 episodes |- | 1983 | ''[[Goodnight, Beantown]]'' | | 1 episode |- | 1984–
1986 | ''[[Benson (TV series)|Benson]]'' | Mrs. Rose Cassidy | Series Regular: Season 7 |- | 1984 | ''[[Newhart]]'' | Ella | 1 episode |- | 1984 | ''[[Happy Days]]'' | Mother Kelp (Marion Cunningham's Mother) | 2 episodes?? |- | 1984 | ''[[Three's a Crowd]]'' |Aunt Mae (Jack Tripper's Aunt) | 1 episode |- | 1985 | ''[[Remington Steele]]'' | Anna Dix | 1 episode |- | 1986 | ''[[Hardcastle and McCormick]]'' | Mimi LeGrand | 1 episode |- | 1986-

1992 | ''[[Dear John (U.S. TV series)|Dear John]]'' | Margie Philbert | 90 episodes |- | 1988 | ''[[Hunter (1984 U.S. TV series)|Hunter]]'' | Marie Watson | 1 episode |- | 1992 | ''[[Murphy Brown]]'' | Ruthie | 1 episode |- | 1993 | ''[[The Wonder Years]]'' | Woman | 2 episodes |- | 1997 | ''[[George and Leo]]'' | | 1 episode |} ==References== {{Reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = }} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} * {{IMDb name|83345}} * {{Amg name|6277}} * {{Find a Grave|6981978}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bird, Billie}} [[Category:Actresses from Idaho]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)]] [[Category:Deaths from Alzheimer's disease]] [[Category:People from Pocatello, Idaho]] [[Category:People from Granada Hills, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:Comedians from Idaho]] [[Category:Comedians from California]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]]
