revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{peacock|date=November 2017}} {{notability|Music|date=October 2017}} }} {{Infobox Musical |name= Wild Side Story |image= Wild Side Story 2001 Logo.jpg |caption= 2001 [[logo]] with silhouette from 1973 and drawing from 1976 }} '''''Wild Side Story''''' is a [[Parody|parody musical]] that originated in 1973 as a [[drag show]] on the gay scene of [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]], soon developed there into an underground [[happening]] for mixed audiences, and up until 2004 was performed hundreds of times in Florida, Sweden, California and Spain.
==Background== [[File:Wild Side Story 1973 first cast.jpg|thumb|The first ''Wild Side Story'' cast at Ambassador III 1973]] [[File:Christer Lindarw & Ulla Jones "Leader of the Pack" Wild Side Story 1976.jpg|thumb|[[Christer Lindarw]] and [[Ulla Jones]] in ''[[Leader of the Pack]]'' in [[Stockholm]] 1976]] [[File:Helena Mattsson & Mohombi Moupondo 2002 (crop).jpg|thumb|[[Helena Mattsson]] and [[Mohombi Moupondo]] after a ''Wild Side Story'' rehearsal in 2002]] Descending from a musical family,<ref>''[[Expressen]]'' (July 19, 1953) p. 3</ref><ref>''[[TV Guide]]'' (June 6, 1959) p. A-38</ref><ref>''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' (September 27, 1985) p. 45</ref> [[Swedish-American]] producer, author and entertainment director Lars Jacob<ref>Betty Skawonius (August 18, 1993) ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' p B03</ref><ref name="Eva">Eva Norlén (July 21, 1997) ''[[Aftonbladet]]'' p. 37</ref> went to [[Florida]] at the age of 22 to work as a desk clerk at the [[Doral Hotel]], and there part-time also continued his recent Swedish career<ref>''VeckoRevyn'' [[Stockholm]] (September 1, 1971) p. 20 "''discjockeyn Lars Jacob ... ledande man bland huvudstadens innefolk'' (disc jockey Lars Jacob ... leading man of the capital city’s in-crowd)"</ref> as a [[disc jockey]].<ref>Perry Fulkerson (November 11, 1971) ''[[Evening Independent]] / The Scene'' pp. 1D, 14D-15D</ref><ref>Herbert R. Hunt's (a.k.a. Johnny Rebel) ''Open Mike'' (November 1, 1971) [[WWMI|WLCY Radio]]</ref> With Logan Carter<ref>James T. Sears in ''Rebels, Rubyfruit, and Rhinestones: Queering Space in the Stonewall South'' {{ISBN|978-0813529646}} pp. 2, 41-47, 73-75, 84-85, 129-130, 154-156, 160-162, 287, 309 - re: career & life of Logan Carter a.k.a. Roxanne Russell</ref> and a handful of young [[Cuba]]n [[refugee]]s who were doing [[Drag queen|drag]] in [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]]<ref name="Eva" /><ref name="Facebook">[[Facebook]] [https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.573763769314925.1073741826.135967279761245&type=1 album introduction] (2013) by Swenglistic Underground</ref> he created a stage show which did a [[Camp (style)|campy]] [[parody]] of ''[[West Side Story]]'', but also included independent material. ''Wild Side Story'' first opened officially at the Ambassador III on August 8, 1973,<ref name="Facebook" /> and by 1974 moved down 22nd Street to [[Stonewall Inn#Riots|Larry Boxx]]'s<ref>[http://www.boxturtlebulletin.com/2015/07/03/70349 Article] by Jim Burroway in ''Box Turtle Bulletin'' 2015-07-02</ref> new Stonewall of Miami Beach; the Florida performances starred Rena Del Rio (Rene Zequeira).<ref name="Kim">Kim Ekemar (January 6, 1976) ''Wild Side Story at Showcase [[Alexandra Charles|Alexandra's]] Stockholm'' ([https://ask.kb.se/F/R4TUDQ2JFSM1M29GJFIEHY2PFLIT4MBVL8MM1NBVQU7KN4363B-02127?func=full-set-set&set_number=012142&set_entry=000002&format=999 playbill] registered at [[National Library of Sweden]]) p. 8</ref>
In 1975 Lars Jacob went back to [[Sweden]] and produced shows for one of the earliest [[Stockholm]] nightclubs<ref>[[Alexandra Charles]] (1986) ''Alexandra on the Rocks'' {{ISBN|91-7684-105-7}} pp. 60-61</ref> [[Alexandra Charles|Alexandra’s]], thus introducing drag shows to Sweden.<ref name="Kalle">Kalle Westerling (2006) ''La Dolce Vita'' {{ISBN|91-85505-15-3}} pp. 20-22</ref> In 1976 he brought his ''Wild Side Story'' to the stage there with local people,<ref name="Kim" /> since a [[Europe]]an [[Concert#Concert tour|tour]], which [[Danny La Rue]]<ref name="Island">''Island Connections'' [[Los Cristianos]] (April 7, 2000) p. 2</ref> had tried to help him set up, had failed to materialize with the Florida cast because of their refugee status.<ref name="Kim" /> A few months later he went back to the [[United States]] and a [[Receptionist|front desk]] job at [[The Beverly Hills Hotel]].<ref name="Eva" /> On the side he again built up an [[Underground music|underground]] [[Ensemble cast|ensemble]] which intermittently played ''Wild Side Story'', with a few adjustments to [[California]]n culture, at alternating venues from 1977 until the beginning of the 1980s, most prominently at [[Thank God It's Friday (film)#Production|Osko's]]. In 1976 his basic [[plot (narrative)|plot]] of ''Wild Side Story'' had been registered with the [[Writers Guild of America West]] by Jacob and business partner Richard Max Mersky of Mimical Productions, and in California they called their show a ''mimical [[Parody|lampoon]]''.<ref name="Rob">Rob Stevens (October 26, 1979) ''Data Boy Pacific Southwest'' [[West Hollywood, California|West Hollywood]] p. 76</ref> A young [[:en:Eric Knight (musician)#Music Industry Career|Ritch M. Esra]] was their [[stage manager]].
Until 2004 the show was performed more than 500 times in Florida,<ref name="Kim" /> Stockholm,<ref name="Eva" /> [[Los Angeles]]<ref name="Michael">[[Michael Kearns]] (November 30, 1979) ''[[San Diego]] Update / L.A. Life'' p. 13</ref> and [[Spain]],<ref name="Island" /> since 1997 called a ''mimical [[humoresque]]''.<ref name="Eva" /> On its 40th anniversary in 2013 the whole ''Wild Side Story'' was played twice again in a 17th-century cellar cave dedicated to [[David (Michelangelo)|Michelangelo's ''David'']] in the [[Gamla stan|Old Town of Stockholm]].<ref name="Facebook" /><ref>''[[Metro International|Metro]]'' Stockholm (August 2, 2013) p. 18</ref><ref>''[[Aftonbladet]]/Nöjesbladet'' (August 2, 2013) p. 25</ref>
==Method== [[Image:Jessica Kilo & Chiena Chinette 1974 Wild Side Story slides.jpg|thumb|left|Two of the [[Reversal film|slides]] used to introduce ''The Dance at the Gym'' since 1974.]] In the beginning all the songs were performed to [[Playback singer|playback]] recordings; later individual combinations of playback, live singing and sound recordings were arranged. That is to say that practically throughout the one-hour show, the cast carried out its roles by [[lip sync]]hing to pre-recorded songs.<ref name="Eva" /><ref name="Göran">Göran Sellgren (January 9, 1976) ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' p. 14</ref> An overdone type of lip and tongue movement enhanced the cast’s [[Satire|satirical]] treatment of the original recordings used,<ref name="Rob" /> and of the plot.
The actors were usually young [[amateur]]s from the respective local scenes, who made their stage [[:wikt:debut|debut]]s,<ref name="Eva" /><ref name="Kim" /> such as designer [[Christer Lindarw]], model Jimmie Kersmo, drama college graduates [[Helena Mattsson]], [[Mohombi Moupondo]] and Patrik Hont, as well as eventual [[Counter Strike]] champion Miguel Bonett. Lars Jacob and his Californian production assistant Rosalie De La Torre have both been given credit for discovering Lindarw, who soon became a big star in Sweden.<ref>[[Christer Lindarw]] and Christina Kellberg in ''This Is My Life'' {{ISBN|978-91-7424-533-2}} pp. 75-76, 122 & 264</ref> In Los Angeles and in later Swedish productions the piece was played by professional casts and with enhanced [[scenography]] and [[technology]].
Three of the nine roles call for male actors to play exaggerated [[drag queen]]s, and since 1976 three of the roles are also cast with three real women,<ref name="Göran" /> one of whom plays a [[drag king]]. Suddenly when an audience is getting used to the constant lip synching, the character Tony breaks out into a live satire on the ''[[Maria (West Side Story song)|Maria]]'' song,<ref name="Rob" /> called ''Maria in Tony's Thoughts''.<ref>[[YouTube]] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eXOERTk-T60 video] (2013) of ''Maria in Tony’s Thoughts''</ref> Show-goers are also taken by surprise with a staged technical failure where one of the actresses stomps her foot and begins swearing out loud till her number just as unexpectedly resumes. [[File:Wild Side Story "America" 1977.jpg|thumb|Steve Vigil as Bernardo and other cast members in ''[[America (West Side Story song)|America]]'', Los Angeles 1977]] A few more effects, such as loud foot drumming in ''[[America (West Side Story song)|America]]'', [[strobe light]]ing to slow motion movement and live screams in the catastrophic street ''Rumble'' – and intermittent projection of [[Reversal film|slide photos]] (some taken in ballet [[Tutu (clothing)|tutus]] in the gymnasium of [[Miami Beach High School]]) and [[Super 8 film]], have completed the multimedia experience.<ref name="Kathy">Kathy Riley (July 16, 1997) ''Stockholm International'' [[SR International – Radio Sweden]]</ref> Recorded [[narration]] was added in Los Angeles in 1977 to help audiences grasp plot [[Continuity (fiction)|continuity]].
Costumes especially designed and created in 1976 by Maria Knutsson of Sweden's popular [[Filippa K#History|Gul&Blå]] boutiques<ref>Kim Ekemar (January 6, 1976) ''Wild Side Story at Showcase Alexandra's Stockholm'' (see above) p. 2</ref> have continued to be used since then, and the same [[body language]] that the director found in the young Cubans already in 1972 has also been preserved to a large extent.
==Parody features== [[File:Wild Side Story "Consuelo's Somewhere" 1979.jpg|thumb|''[[Somewhere (song)|Somewhere]]'' 1979 at [[Thank God It's Friday (film)#Notes|Osko's]] in Los Angeles: Consuelo there was Eddy Hampton Armani who would become [[Tina Turner]]'s unauthorized biographer]] With about half the music from the classic [[Musical theatre|musical]] ''West Side Story'',<ref name="Baren">''Baren'' (June 2000 four segments) [[TV3 (Sweden)]]</ref> in several versions including instrumentals and comedy renditions, of course that musical is parodied,<ref name="Linda">Linda Romanus, ''Tidningen [[Södermalm]] / Nöjesrepubliken'', 24. Juni 2000, S. 22</ref> especially its suicidal ''[[Romeo and Juliet ]]'' theme.
Other songs are included with [[Bette Midler]], [[La Lupe]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Lou Reed]], [[Alma Cogan]] (material provided by [[Adam Faith]]), [[Patti Page]] and [[Peggy Lee]],<ref name="Michael" /><ref name="Linda" /> as well as spicy comments from old [[Mae West]] movie scenes,<ref name="Rob" /><ref name="Göran" /> all creating vital parts of the lampoon. In the [[Finale (music)|finale]], a [[Las Vegas]] performance by [[Diana Ross]] of ''[[Somewhere (song)|Somewhere]]'' comes up, where she quotes "Doctor [[Martin Luther King, Jr.|Martin Luther King]]" and his dream, while [[slot machine]]s are making huge money for the hotel. School dancing, sexual and other [[stereotype]]s, senseless violence, [[Lovesickness|lovesick]] carelessness causing blond drunkenness, [[hippie]] [[hypocrisy]] and the type of [[comedy of errors]] reminiscent of [[Oscar Wilde]] are also parodied. Pick-pockets, male and female [[Chauvinism|chauvinist]] pigs, obstructive false eyelashes, mistaken murder and misplaced false boobs are additional spoofed elements.<ref name="Baren" />
==Plot== The central character José ''Maria'' González dresses up so cleverly as a woman, to try to get a job in a drag show, that Tony falls indiscriminately in love, which leads to the main comedy confusion in the plot,<ref name="Linda" /> and an opening for the cast to satire ''Romeo and Juliet'' rather severely. [[Image:Helena Mattsson "You Don't Know What Love Is" Wild Side Story 2003.jpg|left|thumb|[[Helena Mattsson]]'s ''[[Angst]]'' as a deserted Betty-Sue in ''[[You Don't Know What Love Is]]'' 2003]] Competing for that work, and creating a side plot, are two [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] drag queens Consuelo and Obvióla who make the misunderstood star's life in New York even more miserable, doing ''[[Maria (Rodgers and Hammerstein song)|A Problem Like Maria]]'' in stolen [[Religious habit|nuns’ habits]],<ref name="Rob" /> while Tony stumbles through the streets<ref>Kim Ekemar (January 6, 1976) ''Wild Side Story at Showcase Alexandra's Stockholm'' (see above) p. 4</ref> and sings (even in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] or [[Swedish language|Swedish]] or [[German language|German]] when called for): "Maria, I would never have known or guessed it, but she really is rather flat-chested …".<ref>[[YouTube]] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNFoJlkhBhQ video] (1997) of ''Maria in Tony’s Thoughts''</ref>
Mimed [[Stephen Sondheim|Sondheim]] lyrics are re-performed with new meaning when Maria feels "[[I Feel Pretty|pretty and witty and gay]]" and "hardly can believe I’m real" or an infuriated Anita (to a [[Carol Burnett]] version) shouts "[[A Boy Like That|stick to your own kind]]!". A reinterpretation of the ''[[Tonight (1956 song)|Tonight]]'' song has Tony torn between self-destructive love pangs and ensuing [[Human body|anatomical]] suspicion, while Maria to the audience begins to regret causing so much trouble, just to find employment, and finally removes his girl clothes and make-up.<ref name="Kim" /> [[Shirley Bassey]] supplies the lyric in the [[Drag queen|drag show]] favorite ''This Is My Life''. In ''Wild Side Story'' the singer’s famous female voice gradually becomes secondary to an increasingly reclaimed masculinity performed by the actor.
Eventually, Maria's brother Bernardo and Tony himself and his dumped girlfriend Betty-Sue, created especially for ''Wild Side Story'', all get killed, but they arise from the dead when a fabulously attired soul goddess invokes the spirit of Dr. King (see above) to bring everyone back to life for a ''happy-go-lucky'' ending.
==Reception== [[File:Wild Side Story 1974 Tampa Tour group (2).jpg|thumb|1974 cast members Rena Del Rio, Logan Carter, Peaches Del Monte and Tony Del Valle on tour in [[Tampa]]]] Two of the young Cuban men in the first cast were so convincing as women that a serious and reputable [[Miami]] periodical did a cover story on them as "women who look like women and smell like women and wear frills and satin and ruffles and lace … featuring two such dedicated lovelies modeling the latest in feminine fashions for real women".<ref>Ella Smilkstein (February 1974) ''The [[Miami]] Magazine'' 24:14, cover & pp. 2, 41-42</ref> The first show‘s eventual success has been described by eyewitnesses as "a smash hit … Florida’s great names in female impersonation acted out their bizarre rolls in this bizarre story so the audiences screamed".<ref name="Kim" />
In Stockholm in the autumn of 1975 Lars Jacob, with [[Anders Eljas]] as his debuting band leader and [[Graham Tainton]] as his choreographer, had already succeeded well with his first cabaret ''AlexCab'',<ref>Lisbeth Borger-Bendegard (September 14, 1975) ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]] / I vimlet'' p. 20; (October 24, 1975) p. 17</ref><ref>Lasse (November 21, 1975) ''[[Expressen#GT|Göteborgs-Tidningen]]'' p. 16</ref> where drag numbers of an American type were performed for the first time in Sweden.<ref name="Kalle" /> Respected critic [[Poppius journalistskola|Sten Hedman]] in 1976 called Jacob’s next production ''Wild Side Story'' the "best show in town … decadent, fun, exciting, talented", with the soon famous [[Christer Lindarw]], playing Obvióla, almost [[Prophecy|prophetically]] named as the best in the show.<ref>[[Poppius journalistskola|Sten Hedman]] (January 14, 1976) ''Damernas Värld'' [[Stockholm]] p. 10</ref> Writers in major newspapers like ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' and '' [[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' noticeably had a hard time knowing whether to praise or bash such a totally new phenomenon as ''Wild Side Story'', and their reviews came out somewhat perplexed.<ref>Oscar Hedlund (January 17, 1976) ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'' p. 17</ref> The latter of the two did single out Steve Vigil in the leading role, as well as [[Ulla Jones]] as Betty-Sue and [[Cabaret#Swedish cabaret (from 1970s)|Agneta Lindén]] as Anita, for charisma and knowhow.<ref name="Göran" /> (Vigil had seen ''Wild Side Story'' in Florida as early as 1974 and went on after Stockholm to play Bernardo in the California production 1977-1980.)<ref name="Rob" /> [[File:Steve Vigil & Lars Jacob 1974.jpg|left|thumb|Steve Vigil and Lars Jacob at the ''Miss [[David Atlanta|David]] Pageant'' in Florida in 1974.]] A few years later in Los Angeles, journalist [[Michael Kearns]] headlined his review with ''Wild Side Story'' as "the talk of the town", mentioned celebrities in the audience (such as [[Lehman Engel]] and [[Boz Scaggs]]) and added "the most unusual thing you’ve ever seen",<ref name="Michael" /> while a local gay magazine called it a "fun, campy evening’s entertainment" and "the cast is lively and Jacob’s direction is fast paced … a dashing Tony … beautiful, touching, tender Maria …" and the two drag queens "the riotous part of the show".<ref name="Rob" />
[[File:Wild Side Story Spain Tour 2000 (1).jpg|thumb|Cast members in [[Puerto Rico de Gran Canaria]] in Spain in 2000]] In 1997, again in Stockholm, reviewers made comments like "a completely wild evening"<ref name="Eva" /> and "a hilarious parody, an inspiring show of ingenuity, an alternative hysterical",<ref name="Kathy" /> and in Spain in 2000 the show’s and its director’s histories were highlighted advantageously.<ref name="Island" /> Later that year another Stockholm writer for the first time called ''Wild Side Story'' a "[[Cult following|cult show]]".<ref name="Linda" /> In 2003 and 2004 the capital city‘s tourism people in their magazine called the piece "a cult classic … wonderful evening of singing, dancing and music in a fast-paced parody", with "laughter, fun, pantomime, dancing and music, ''Wild Side Story'' pokes fun at the foibles of human behavior and much more".<ref>''What’s On'' by the City of [[Stockholm]] (July 2003) p. 16; (July 2004) p. 12</ref> In 2003 the drag queens were noted by Sweden’s leading [[gay]] publication as played by "rather beefy guys with hairy armpits".<ref>''[[QX (magazine)|QX]]'' (August 2003)</ref>
==Core themes== [[File:Lars Jacob, Gert Fylking & Wild Side Story cast 1997.jpg|thumb|Lars Jacob with 1997 cast members at the end of a TV interview conducted by [[Gert Fylking]]]] Lars Jacob has been interviewed on television in Sweden about ''Wild Side Story''. In a live broadcast for the public access station [[List of television stations in Sweden#Public access stations|Öppna Kanalen]] in 1997 he said: "Since I was 13-14 years old I’ve always found it so confusing with all the sexual [[hypocrisy]] we have in society, and religious hypocrisy and political hypocrisy, so I’m an anti-hypocrisy fanatic – that’s the only thing I’m fanatic about, being against hypocrisy – so that makes it great fun to joke around with double standards and the over-[[Romance (love)|romantization]] of society, which means that young people hardly have a chance to make it, with all this propaganda we have for romance.“<ref>[[List of television stations in Sweden#Public access stations|Öppna Kanalen]] Stockholm (July 22, 1997)</ref>
Again in 2000 he appeared as the director of ''Wild Side Story'' on [[TV3 (Sweden)|Channel 3]] in four segments of a popular TV series by [[Strix (TV production company)|Strix]] (''[[The Bar (TV series)|Baren]]''), where he said "there’s nothing really lewd in the show, but there’s a lot of fun poked at sexuality and romance and ''True Love'' and all that", and speaking of yet another brave cast of his, "I think it‘s great with people who dare, and people who make something special out of life, not like [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland|Princess Madeleine]] like 'I want to live a regular life' – huh? My God! She belongs to five of the most unusual families in the world, this girl, and the poor thing is forced to say things like 'I want to live a regular life'!".<ref name="Baren" />
== External links == {{Commons category}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3O6vouaRqso YouTube] ''Wild Side Story'' 1973-1975 in Florida (excerpt stills) *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i3bbcm5_vbM YouTube] ''Wild Side Story'' 1976 in Stockholm (excerpt stills & film) *[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLOV2tY8Scs08biLNoc3eCmGCy1C-I_5Ol Playlist on YouTube] ''Wild Side Story'' 1979 in Los Angeles & 1997-1998 in Stockholm (whole show)
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Revues]]

revision.text:
[[File:Zelda Russell LCCN2014718691.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Zella Russell]] '''Rosella O'Connor Russell''' (October 24, 1883 - February 1, 1952) was a [[vaudeville]] star from about 1912 to the late 1940s on the [[Columbia circuit]].<ref>''The Washington Post'', many articles advertising Columbia circuit shows.</ref> <!--Possibly Zella O. Russell 24 Oct 1883 Worcester, Massachusetts-->
==Biography== She was born in the [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]] area of [[Massachusetts]] and began her career as a pianist in the [[Silent film|silent movie]] theaters the Palace and the Dreamland in the [[Boston]] area. She moved into vaudeville, joining Al Reeves show "Big Burlesque Review" both with a piano act and acting in light [[comedy routine]]s. Her piano specialty was playing pop tunes of the day in a classical arrangement. Her playing was so popular that it often "stopped" the show, the audience demanding she keep playing. Newspaper profiles of the day credit her with attending the [[New England Conservatory of Music]], but this cannot be confirmed by their records.
She married [[Harry Kennedy Morton]], a fellow vaudevillian.<ref name=morton>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Harry K. Morton, Ex-Vaudevillian. Musical Comedy Player in 1920's Dies. Was Dancer, Singer and Prizefighter |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E04E1DE163BE53ABC4952DFB366838D649EDE |quote=Harry K. Morton, vaudeville and musical comedy player, died Wednesday of cancer of the throat in the Roosevelt Hospital. He was 67 years old. ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=May 11, 1956 |accessdate=2014-07-22 }}</ref> She had one son, Harold Morton, Jr., who died in childhood.
She died in February 1, 1952 in the [[Somerville, Massachusetts]] area. Her husband died in May 1956.<ref name=morton/>
==Broadway productions== *''Blossom Time'', Sep 4, 1943 - Oct 9, 1943, as Mrs. Kranz *''Blossom Time'', Dec 26, 1938 - Jan 1939, as Mrs. Kranz *''The Love Song'', Jan 13, 1925 - Jun 6, 1925, as Lizette *''Springtime of Youth'', Oct 26, 1922 - Dec 23, 1922, as Pepita *''The Sweetheart Shop'', Aug 31, 1920 - Oct 16, 1920, as Daphne<ref>http://www.ibdb.com/person.php?id=58701</ref>
==Filmography== *''[[Avenging Waters]]'' (1936) as "Mrs. Eloise Smythe" *''[[Taming the Wild]]'' (1936) as "Mrs. Elizabeth Bolton"<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0751521/</ref>
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== *''Boxoffice Magazine'', Feb. 16, 1952 issue, pages 97 and 98 *''The Washington Post'', December 9, 1917, "Makes Classics of Ragtime"
==External links== {{commons category|Zella Russell}} *{{IMDb name|id=0751521|name=Zella Russell}} *{{IBDB name|id=58701}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Russell, Zella}} [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:People from Worcester County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:Actresses from Massachusetts]]
{{entertainer-stub}}
